skill.name: reflect-on-work
skill.description: Pattern for producing quality reflections after completing work. Required for all agent outputs.
skill.summary: Pattern for producing quality reflections after completing work. Required for all agent outputs.
skill.author: Clouder0

security_audit.summary: Pure markdown documentation skill defining reflection output format. No executable code, no network access, no filesystem operations, no command execution. Contains only JSON schema examples and documentation.

content.value_statement: Agents need to capture learnings after tasks. This skill provides a structured reflection pattern for generating quality post-task reflections. It ensures every task contributes to organizational knowledge.
actual_capabilities: Generates structured reflection output with knowledge updates
Defines categories for different types of learnings
Provides confidence levels for captured knowledge
Captures successful strategies and failed approaches
limitations: Requires agents to implement the output format
Cannot analyze reflections without separate tooling

use_cases.title: Capture Codebase Insights
use_cases.description: Document discovered patterns, conventions, and architectural decisions while exploring unfamiliar code.

use_cases.title: Track Task Outcomes
use_cases.description: Record what strategies worked or failed during task execution to improve future planning.

use_cases.title: Study Agent Behavior
use_cases.description: Analyze patterns noticed across many agent runs to improve system design.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Reflection
prompt_templates.prompt: Reflect on what you just accomplished. What worked? What failed? What patterns did you notice?

prompt_templates.title: Codebase Insights
prompt_templates.prompt: Document the key things you learned about this codebase. Include conventions, gotchas, and structure.

prompt_templates.title: Pattern Identification
prompt_templates.prompt: Look across your recent work. What patterns keep appearing? What should be extracted as reusable skills?

prompt_templates.title: Knowledge Aggregation
prompt_templates.prompt: Summarize all knowledge updates from this session. What category does each belong to? How confident are you?

output_examples.input: Reflect on completing the authentication feature implementation.
output: - what_worked: Parallel exploration found context quickly; starting with types helped structure code
- what_failed: Initial test approach was wrong; spent time on wrong file before exploring
- patterns_noticed: Error handling uses Result type; tests colocated with source files

best_practices: Be specific and actionable rather than vague or generic
Be honest about failures; they provide valuable learning opportunities
Keep reflections concise; focus on insights that inform future work
anti_patterns: Writing generic reflections that could apply to any task
Including excessive detail without clear takeaways
Delaying reflection until end of session instead of completing per task

faq.question: What tools support this skill?
faq.answer: All Claude Code agents, Claude, and Codex support the reflection output format defined by this skill.

faq.question: How often should I reflect?
faq.answer: Complete reflection after every significant task. Small tasks can use brief reflections; complex tasks need detailed ones.

faq.question: How does this integrate with existing workflows?
faq.answer: Agents include reflection output in their completion payload. The skill defines the structure; agents implement the inclusion.

faq.question: Is my reflection data stored securely?
faq.answer: Reflections are stored according to your agent's configuration. This skill only defines the format, not storage.

faq.question: What if my reflections conflict with previous ones?
faq.answer: Review confidence levels and update knowledge base with higher-confidence findings. Mark conflicts for human review.

faq.question: How is this different from simple task summaries?
faq.answer: Reflections focus on meta-learning: what worked, what failed, and patterns noticedâ€”not just what was done.
